Wildfires are a natural part of healthy ecological systems, but uncontrolled fires near the Wildland/Urban Interface (WUI) pose a significant threat to life and property. The effects of climate change are expected to lead to increased intensity and severity of wildfires. To combat this complex problem, updated modeling and mitigation techniques are necessary. Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) can be applied to wildland fire modeling, forecasting, and optimized mitigation planning, but these methods require large datasets representative of historical events.

Currently, datasets in this domain are limited, and data sources are spread across multiple agencies with incompatible formats and often non-overlapping or misaligned spatiotemporal fire spread and mitigation tracking. Fire projection models are essential tools in firefighting training, fire planning, risk modeling, and real-time incident response. However, these models have limitations, as they were developed by studying small, well-contained wildfires or physics-based simulations and were not explicitly validated against historical data.

To address this issue, a novel dataset, Burn Mitigation Dataset (BurnMD), is presented. This dataset consists of 308 medium-sized fires from 2018 to 2021, including time series airborne-based inference and ground operational estimation of fire extent, as well as operational mitigation data such as control line construction. BurnMD is the first large wildfire dataset with mitigation information and will help advance fire projection modeling, fire risk modeling, and AI-generated land management policies.

The lack of standardization among agencies that collect wildfire data limits innovation. This work aims to serve as a standardized dataset that can be used in downstream efforts for modeling and predicting wildfire spread and mitigation techniques, enabling the wildfire community to validate and verify future modeling techniques.

Related work in other domains, such as tsunami, hurricane, and flood modeling, has shown the importance of standardized and verified data. In contrast, wildfire models are not updated, standardized, or verified across historical databases. Researchers have curated datasets for wildfire and fire events in the past, but little attention has been paid to the role of human intervention in wildfire progression. This work contributes the first wildland fire dataset that includes community mitigation efforts, which is essential for representing the behavior seen by fire managers and reducing the risk of loss of life, property, and ecology.

The dataset used in this work includes Final Fire Perimeters, Operational Mitigations, and Operational Base Camps and Water/Retardant Drop Sites, which are publicly available through the National Interagency Fire Center (NIFC) Open Data Site. To verify dates and add missing flight times, MODIS and VIIRS data are leveraged.
